title: Measuring Power & Building Impacts Cohort
text:
Measuring Power & Building Impacts Cohort
Context: Peopleâ€™s Action Institute has been engaging in a long term project partnering with The Movement Cooperative and working through the PAI power building team to build definitions, metrics and best practices. Additionally, we are working to meet the moment around the need for CRM migrations as the current available tools become less viable for our organizations.
Given the viability of available tools, and their ability to meet our power building needs, this cohort is ideally about the work of cleaning data and preparing for migration from current systems/CRMS to ActionNetwork/ActionBuilder & fundraising platform of the institutionâ€™s choice.
Purpose & Expectation: This is a working space that will function as a working group that will utilize a training of trainers format for many of the sessions, in order to prepare participants to bring the content and work back to their organization each month.
This cohort will only be as useful and successful as your ability to commit to the work in between sessions. These sessions will also build on each other, in order to be ready to move the process of migration it is necessary that cohort members commit to attending every session and that organizations have two participants, one data staff and an organizing director or lead organizer who can drive the process on power building culture and rigor.
Organizational Outcomes:

Organizations will have interrogated and evaluated their culture of data tracking and maintenance and the impact that culture and practice has on their power building.
Organizations will use this assessment to make shifts in culture and protocol for tracking power building.
Organizations will have worked a process to clean up current systems and data to prepare for migration, or to implement better practices in current database
Organizations will have the data, tools and organizational culture shifts in place to finalize migration and/or the ability to track power building impact more effectively in current systems at the end of this cohort

title: Timeline
text:
Month
Topic & Summary




July
Welcome and Overview
Participants will review the migration cohort timeline and understand the key milestones ahead. They will establish a shared grounding and data practice philosophy to guide decisions and ensure consistency. By the end, all participants will articulate their commitment and clearly define the expected outcomes of the CRM migration.


August
What are your current data practices and setup?
Participants will be provided a facilitatorâ€™s guide to document existing tools, culture, and infrastructure at their own organization.
They will evaluate if current practices set them up for success in the CRM migration.
Using the guide, each team will map their DARCIs to clarify roles and capacity for data management at their respective organization.


September
What is useful to track?
Participants will review the leadership ladder workbook to identify common events, roles, matching criteria, thresholds, visualize results, and reflect on next questions to be taken back to their organization.
They will learn why maintaining data freshness matters more than collecting stale data and why not everything belongs in the CRM.
By the end, each team will prioritize 5â€“10 key metrics that align with their ladder of engagement.


October
Best practices and institutionalizing data practices
Participants will explore cultural eventsâ€”Data entry parties, weekly leaderboards, and moreâ€”to embed data in everyday routines.
They will map data tasks into managerâ€“managee workflows and design standard processes that feed the CRM.
By session end, teams will implement rigorous data practices to empower the organization and sustain a data-driven culture.


November
Data and access - who has it and how to define access
Participants will answer key questions about database administrators, power users, member leader access, and existing bottlenecks.
They will pinpoint unnecessary control points and recommend adjustments to streamline permissions.
By session end, each team will have a clear data access framework that ensures secure, efficient workflows.


December - No Meeting


January
Change management: Preparing your organization for the migration
Participants will outline stakeholder communication plans, training schedules, and adoption strategies to secure buy-in.
They will identify change champions, map resistance points, and assign support roles.
By the end, teams will present a draft change management plan with clear milestones, responsibilities, and success metrics.


February
-
April
Data Cleanup Session One, Two, and Three
Participants will use insights from earlier modules to audit and cleanse key datasetsâ€”deciding what to keep, archive, or compress based on freshness.
They will tackle tags, survey responses, people records, donations, events, addresses, duplicates, inactive records, opt-outs, and leadership ladder data.
By the end, each team will deliver a prioritized, cleaned dataset complete with documented archiving rules and quality controls.


May
Integrating the Peopleâ€™s Action leadership ladder framework
Participants will study the leadership ladder framework from Peopleâ€™s Action and The Movement Cooperative.
They will define automated rules that advance records as engagement thresholds are met.
By session end, teams will deploy a configured ladder system to benchmark the organizing revival and generate network-wide insights


June
Migration Contractor Preparations
Participants will take all of the materials built out during the cohort and compile it into one document that will be handed off to the migration contractor.


July
Migrations Happening - Onboarding Admins
Participants will learn the structured admin onboarding process, covering the CRM structure, user roles, and governance policies.
They will practice configuring admin accounts, assigning permissions, and customizing dashboards according to organizational standards.
They will develop training materials and support protocols to ensure new admins can effectively manage and maintain the CRM.


August
Migrations Happening - Onboarding Staff Users and Member Leaders
Participants will learn to define user personas for staff and member leaders, mapping their CRM access levels and workflows.
They will practice setting up accounts, permissions, and customized dashboards to meet each roleâ€™s needs.
They will review tailored onboarding guides, training sessions, and support materials to drive adoption and proficiency


ðŸŽ‰ Cohort Completed ðŸŽ‰


September
-
December
Bi-Weekly Office Hours for Admins and Users

title: 2Â  What are your current data practices and setup?
text:
Takeaway

Steps 1, 2a and 2b of the Data Map Visualization for Basebuilding and Leadership Development Metrics
Tech Stack Mapping
Survey of the tools:

Have your staff take a survey of all the tools that have been identified
Have them self identify the role that they use the tool from:

Organizers / Staff
Leaders
Managers
Admin

Then have people answer the following questions (for each tool):

On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being never heard of it, 10 being that you use it all the time; How familiar are you with this tool?
On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being not useful at all, 10 being extremely useful; How useful is this tool to your workflow?
Do you use an alternative tool instead of this tool for the purpose it provides? If so, what is that tool, and why do you use it?


Discussion with organizers about tool usage:

We recommend this being a separate call so that the conversations are able to have the time they need for solid discussion.
Questions:

What are your current practices around data entry and measuring power/leadership development? What is hard about tracking and measuring your base? How is the organizing culture of the organization set up to support this rigor? How might it not be?
Are you tracking your base in your database or at least on paper? What metrics or data points are you tracking about leadership? Are you propositioning people in powerful ways? Are you doing many 1:1s? And are you tracking this data somewhere? Are you tracking too much or too little?
What is your current user rate for your tool stack and culture of practice to use these tools?

What currently does and does not work with your current tool stack?
What is the level of usage of the tools for your base building/organizing?
What is getting in the way? (time, training, accountability etc)
